p: Vector-borne diseases pose a significant threat to human life and welfare and account for approximately 17% of the global burden of infectious diseases, causing more than one million deaths each year [ 1]. More than 80% of the worldâ€™s population live in areas with at least one major vector-borne disease risk, with more than half of the population facing two or more such risks [ 1]. For most vector-borne diseases, prevention by targeting vectors is the first and best approach. Use of long clothing and topical repellents for personal protection is one of proven effective vector control approaches. When considering the adverse environmental effects and the development of resistance to synthetic repellents, there is currently a greater requirement for plant-based repellents [ 2].
